Alan,

Your argument assumes that the wealthy are wealthy because they provide a net benefit to society. Yet all of the activities you cited are only done in order to profit. Profit is nothing less that taking more than you need from a closed system. By taking in more money than you circulate through the system, you crate a deficiency elsewhere in the system. It is no secret that a few people sit on vast fortunes. And those vast fortunes could carry the futures of millions of families to a better condition. But that wealth is kept out of the general system. And so, others are forced to do without. This is what is happening now. And as we can see, it represents a far greater drain on the economy than the total number of welfare recipients combined. TARP swallowed up over 8 trillion dollars. What does an average family cost per year? 50k?

The system is not the problem. The problem is the incorrect application of our interpersonal relationships. If we related to each other correctly, then we would correct the functioning of our social and economic systems to reflect this correction in perception. As it stands we created these systems because we need to cooperate in order to survive. But we corrupt these systems because we relate to each other from hatred. We must learn to correct our relationships by learning to live outside our own personal interests. This is Human work. And without it we won't solve anything. http://www.perceivingreality.com

Peace to you and yours.

Much of the 'massive infusion of cash' depends on the assumption that financial institutions always have to get their money back and make a profit, even if everybody else goes to hell in a handbasket. The greed of banks, as well as the unrealistic behavior of people and governments, has put many of them in a situation that will lead to their collapse. Some major banks 'will no longer be able to finance further growth' because they will no longer exist. Most of the money borrowed in Europe and in the US has not gone to finance further growth in any meaningful way. It has gone to finance unsustainable lifesyles.
"Growth for the sake is the ideology of a cancel cell" (aka American Capitalsim) doesn't work either.

It is a bit disingenuous to call the current economic events in Europe a "Failed Course." the problem is so interconnected that just keeping the system stable is going to take some hared choices from all the countries.

The ECB can only put so much money into the system before it causes a high inflation rate devaluing the Euro. A devalued Euro will make Germany's exports more expensive, slowing down their economy. If Greece is forced to default, several large banks will lose capital and be unable to finance further growth.

Spain and Portugal are also debtor countries and they are going deeper into debt, but if they can not pay their bonds, it will also put the banks at risk which can cause a run on the banks and bank failures. That would freeze credit and send all of the Euro countries into a deep depression.

So what you see is an interdependence that simply can not just be dismissed. We see that cutting back on government spending decreases revenue, but these governments have nothing left to spend. The banks have to take a cut to keep them from defaulting altogether.

It is going to take a massive infusion of of funds to keep this from happening, but where is this cash going to come from?

I don't understand the story. If the bottom rate is 15% for dividends, how can anyone be paying less than 15% on their income. If they are saying that "income" is what is received before deductions are taken, that is not really correct since the whole point of deductions is to remove things that aren't really income. For example, if you make $10 M but give $9 M away, your income is really only $1M.

What should be deductible is another debate. I just want to know if anyone is actually paying less than 15% on their income after deductions, or is the rate cited in the story saying that the income is the amount before deductions. For example, if you pay 15% on the $1 M after you gave $9 M away in my example above. is he saying that is just paying 1.5% since you are only paying $150,000 on $10M?

Anyone know?

There you go again buying hook, line, and sinker the lie that if we tax the wealthy less, they will invest, improving the economy. They might in fact invest, but their investments do not necessarily create jobs. E.g., buying $1,000,000 worth of stock does NOT create jobs, it just allows the investor to receive dividends and/or capital gains. That's because the stock purchased had already been issued and the company it represents didn't use the proceeds it to invest and create more jobs. No, that $1,000,000 went to another investor who had owned the stock.

There is  nothing at all ridiculous about taxing dividends at a lower rate than other income; it is done in one way or other in virtually every other major industrial country.    Investing is not a business for most people; if it is for you   congratulations.    Most people who understand basic economics see a corporation that earns $100x, pays $30x (or whatever) in total taxes, keeps some for working capital and distributes maybe $50x to its shareholders AFTER TAX.     If the $50x is then taxed at 35% to the shareholders after already having been taxed at the corporate level, it is obvious to any non-ideologue that there has been double taxation.

Your argument appeals to folks who have no understanding and therefore jump on the bandwagon to demagogue others who put their money at risk by investing in companies who create jobs and fuel the economy. The “20% of the richest people in the country” already pay many times more than “twice as much as others who are much poorer than they” are.

The richest 20% of taxpayers — which represents over 58 million individuals — collectively pay almost nineteen times (19x) as much in taxes as the poorest 20% of taxpayers. In fact, the richest 20% of taxpayers pay more in federal, state and local (including Social Security) taxes than all other taxpayers combined. When all taxes are considered, this group pays almost 53% of taxes — not 44%.

And when the recipients of government spending are calculated, the poorest three-fifths of taxpayers receive more from all levels of government than they pay in taxes. In other words, a small group of productive Americans support a very large group who are not.

Also, the richest Americans pay a larger share of the tax burden than the richest Europeans — even when compared against their share of income. The United States has a more progressive tax system than other industrialized democracy, including France, Germany, Sweden or Italy.

Complete data can be found in The Tax Foundation's Special Report on Who Pays America's Tax Burden, and Who Gets the Most Government Spending? and in the OECD report Growing Unequal? Income Distribution and Poverty in OECD Countries.
